instruction: Convert this cooking video transcript into a structured recipe.
input:
Nick:
I'm going to teach you everything you need to
know about steak. In this video, you'll learn how to cook the
perfect steak as well as which steaks you should buy and more importantly, which
steaks not to buy. I'll also demonstrate the most popular
cooking methods, including grilled, seared, reverse seared sous vide and broiled. I guarantee that if you watch this video,
you'll be a steak expert for life First. What makes a good steak? It all comes down to just one word: balance. And with steak, balance comes down to just
two main things flavor and texture. You've probably heard the saying fat is
flavor. Those little white fatty spots in meat are
called marbling. When steak cooks, that fat melts into the
meat and keeps it tender and juicy while adding tons of great flavor. That's why it's so important to have that
nice balance of fat. Those shots you just saw were Japanese a5
Wagyu, the nicest beef in the entire world. Different countries have their own grading
systems for marbling. The three main systems coming from the
United States, Australia and Japan. These charts all rate based on the marbling,
meaning that the better the marbling, the more you'll probably pay. In front of me is
every single type of steak that comes from a cow before we cook. It is very important
that you understand which steaks come from, which portion of the cow, so that you'll be
able to choose the right steak for you. You might already think you know which steaks
you like best, but what you're about to learn may completely change your mind. As I go through the steaks, I'm also going
to add anywhere between 1 and $4 signs to show how expensive the steaks are here. I've broken down this cow into a few
different sections. You can get steak from the chuck rib loin
flank and plate sections. Cuts that come from the round shank and brisket sections cannot
be cooked as a steak and typically have to be cooked low and slow. So even though I do love a good brisket, I
won't be discussing those today. Let's start with the Chuck section. From here we get the Chuck steak, which I
love because it comes from the first couple of cuts on the Chuck and is actually pretty
similar to a ribeye steak but is much cheaper in price. The flatiron comes from the
shoulder of the cow and is extremely tender with a good balance of marbling and an
intense beefy flavor. Moving on to the rib section, we've got a
ribeye steak, which is my personal favorite. It has fantastic marbling and also contains
the cap, which is probably the best tasting meat in the entire cow. I'll demonstrate later in the video how to
cook it and how to cut it. The loin section is a very tender part of
the cow, which makes for juicy but often very expensive steaks. You'll probably recognize
a lot of these. One of my favorites that comes from here is
the sirloin cap, popularly known as the Picanha. This is one of the most prized
steaks in all of Brazil, where it's often cooked over open flame. It's tender and juicy with a rich, beefy
flavor and has a beautiful fat cap. The sirloin steak and the New York strip are
both less fatty than the ribeye with a great balance of tenderness and leanness. But I'd still choose a ribeye any day. The Porterhouse and T-Bone are both very
similar in the sense that both steaks contain two cuts in one, both the filet and the
strip. The difference is the porterhouse has a
larger fillet and more fat content, which makes my personal preference the porterhouse
over the T-Bone. Just be careful when cooking either of these
steaks because you're basically cooking two different steaks at the exact same time,
which can make it hard to cook both perfectly. The filet mignon and the
tenderloin both also come from the same section, but are highly overrated. Given how expensive these two cuts are, I
would suggest using your money to get something with more fat and therefore more
flavor. Tri tip can also be tasty and typically has
great marbling, but it's very tough and unforgiving if you overcook it. So I don't recommend this cut either. From the flank section comes the flank
steak, which is probably most recognizable as the beef that comes in your beef and
broccoli. If you order Chinese takeout, if you marinate
it properly and cook it through to medium, it's delicious. Last but not least, we have
the short plate section. My favorite steak from here being the skirt
steak, specifically the outside skirt, which is more tender than the inside. Later in this video, we will cook and cut a
skirt steak. And I really want to focus on the cutting
portion of that because despite this being one of my favorite steaks out there, I was
cutting it incorrectly most of my life. The final steak. And one of my other
personal favorites is the hanger steak. Let me tell you, if you haven't tried a
hanger steak, you need to. It's also known as the butcher steak, since
butchers used to save this one for themselves. Trust me when I say you need to
try this one, you should use all of that information to find the best combination
between flavor, cost and texture that works best for you. If you're still confused on
what steaks to buy, ask your butcher or the person behind the meat counter at the
supermarket. I know they might look intimidating at
times, but trust me when I say that they're gentle giants and they want to help you. Now that you know what steaks to buy,
there's just one last step before cooking. Seasoning. And the best part is it's very
simple. You'll just season with a high quality salt
at least an hour before cooking your steak, if not overnight. This process is called dry
brining, and it's seasons. The whole steak, not just the very outside,
which is what happens if you only salt right before cooking. Dry brining allows the salt
to go into the meat so you get that flavor everywhere. You can also get creative with
your seasoning and use a marinade which works particularly well on steaks such as flank
steak and strip steak. I've seen tons of comments in the past
asking me where my seasoning is if I've only used salt and pepper on a steak. But remember, there is nothing wrong with
letting the flavor of steak speak for itself. Now that our steaks are seasoned, how do we
know which method to cook them with? There are plenty to choose from, but we'll do the best and most popular grilling,
searing, reverse, searing sous vide and broiling. And the best way to decide how to

way to cook a steak, grilling. And as always, I'm looking for maximum
flavor. So I'm going to start with the best charcoal

chimney starter, I'm going to go ahead and use my little trick of using Doritos as a

fully on fire, at which point we want to let that die down to get these nice red, white,

When it comes to searing, I actually

output:
**Perfect Steak Guide**

**Ingredients:**
* 1 steak of choice (such as ribeye, hanger, skirt, or picanha), at least 1-inch thick for most methods
* High-quality coarse salt (such as kosher salt)
* Freshly cracked black pepper
* 2 tablespoons high-smoke-point oil (such as avocado or canola), for searing methods
* 2 tablespoons unsalted butter, for butter basting (optional)
* 2 garlic cloves, smashed (optional, for butter basting)
* 2 sprigs fresh rosemary or thyme (optional, for butter basting)

**Instructions:**
1. **Season & Dry Brine:** At least 1 hour (or up to overnight) before cooking, generously season the steak on all sides with salt. Place on a wire rack set over a baking sheet and refrigerate uncovered.
2. **Prepare Cooking Method:**
    * **For Grilling:** Light charcoal and let it burn until covered with white-gray ash, or preheat a gas grill to high (about 450-500°F / 230-260°C).
    * **For Searing:** Place a cast-iron skillet over medium-high heat until very hot. Add the oil just before cooking.
    * **For Reverse Sear:** Preheat oven to 250°F (120°C). Place the seasoned steak on a wire rack over a baking sheet. Cook until the internal temperature reaches 115-125°F (46-52°C), about 30-45 minutes depending on thickness.
    * **For Sous Vide:** Set a precision cooker to your desired final temperature (e.g., 130°F/54°C for medium-rare). Vacuum-seal the seasoned steak and cook in the water bath for 1-4 hours.
    * **For Broiling:** Position an oven rack 4-6 inches from the broiler element and preheat the broiler to high.
3. **Cook the Steak:**
    * **Grill (Thick Cuts):** For steaks over 1-inch thick (like ribeye), first sear over direct heat to develop a crust, then move to indirect heat, cover, and cook until the desired internal temperature is reached.
    * **Grill (Thin Cuts):** For thin steaks (like skirt), cook entirely over high direct heat, flipping once, until done.
    * **Sear:** Add steak to the hot, oiled pan. Press down gently. Sear without moving until a deep brown crust forms, about 2-4 minutes. Flip and sear the other side. For butter basting, reduce heat, add butter and aromatics, tilt the pan, and spoon the foaming butter over the steak for the last 1-2 minutes.
    * **Reverse Sear Finish:** After the oven step, sear the steak in a very hot, oiled skillet for 60-90 seconds per side to develop a crust.
    * **Sous Vide Finish:** Remove steak from bag and pat it very dry with paper towels. Sear in a very hot, oiled skillet for 60-90 seconds per side until a crust forms.
    * **Broil:** Place steak on a sheet tray. Broil for 4-6 minutes per side, flipping once, until a crust forms and desired doneness is reached.
4. **Check Temperature & Rest:** Use an instant-read thermometer to check doneness (125°F/52°C for rare, 130°F/54°C for medium-rare, 140°F/60°C for medium). Transfer the steak to a cutting board, optionally top with herbs, and let rest for 5-10 minutes. The temperature will rise 5-10°F (3-5°C) during resting.
5. **Slice & Serve:** Always slice the steak against the grain (across the direction of the muscle fibers). For a whole picanha or skirt steak, identify the grain direction before slicing. Pour any accumulated resting juices over the sliced steak.

**Tips:**
- Let the steak develop a crust by not moving it frequently during searing or grilling.
- To render a fat cap (like on a ribeye or picanha), start cooking with the fatty edge down in the pan or on the grill.
- When slicing, drag the cut pieces through the juices left on the cutting board after resting.
- For a quick marinade, use a vacuum sealer to rapidly infuse flavors in about 15 minutes.

output:
**Perfect Vanilla Cake**

**Ingredients:**
* 2 ½ cups (280g) all-purpose flour
* 2 ¼ teaspoons baking powder
* ¾ teaspoon salt
* ¾ cup (170g) unsalted butter, room temperature
* 1 ⅔ cups (333g) granulated sugar
* 3 large eggs, room temperature
* 1 tablespoon (15ml) vanilla extract
* 1 cup buttermilk, room temperature
* Butter and parchment paper for pans
* Vanilla buttercream frosting (for assembly)

**Instructions:**
1. Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease two 8-inch round cake pans with butter and line the bottoms with parchment paper circles.
2. In a medium bowl, sift together the flour, baking powder, and salt. Whisk to combine and set aside.
3. In the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the paddle attachment, cream the room-temperature butter on medium speed until smooth.
4. With the mixer running, gradually add the granulated sugar. Increase speed to high and beat for 3 minutes until light and fluffy. Stop to scrape down the bowl and paddle halfway through.
5. Reduce speed to medium. Add the eggs one at a time, allowing each to fully incorporate before adding the next. Scrape down the bowl.
6. Mix in the vanilla extract.
7. With the mixer on its lowest speed, add the dry ingredients and buttermilk in three alternating additions, beginning and ending with the dry ingredients. Mix only until almost combined; some streaks of flour should remain.
8. Finish mixing the batter by hand with a spatula until just combined and no dry pockets remain.
9. Divide the batter evenly between the prepared pans (about 600g per pan). Tap the pans firmly on the counter to release large air bubbles.
10. Bake for about 30 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean. For flatter layers, wrap the pans with damp cake strips before baking.
11. Let cakes cool in the pans for 10 minutes, then turn out onto a wire rack to cool completely before frosting.
12. To assemble, place one cake layer on a plate or cake stand. Spread a generous layer of vanilla buttercream over the top. Place the second layer on top.
13. Apply a thin crumb coat of frosting over the entire cake and smooth. Chill briefly if needed, then apply the final layer of frosting and decorate as desired.

**Tips:**
- For best results, measure flour by weight. If using cups, fluff the flour, spoon it into the cup, and level it off.
- Ensure all refrigerated ingredients (butter, eggs, buttermilk) are at room temperature before mixing to ensure even baking and a flat top.
- Avoid overmixing the batter once the flour is added to prevent a tough, gummy texture. Mix only until just combined.
- A crumb coat (a thin initial layer of frosting) helps trap loose crumbs for a clean final finish.

input: Hey everybody, let's turn these eggs into fluffy Japanese pancakes! Give those eggs a good crack and separate the yolks from the whites. Making these pancakes fluffy might seem like rocket science, but don't sweat it. I've got all the tricks up my sleeve, and I'm spilling them in this video. Don't go anywhere unless you're heading out for eggs. Throw a splash of milk into the yolks. Milk helps to create a lighter, fluffier texture by adding moisture and contributing to the overall batter consistency. Adding vanilla extract would be a great touch; just make sure you don't accidentally use soy sauce instead. Unless you're feeling adventurous and really into unique flavors. Alright, let's add the flour. I'm a sifting nerd, but if you just dump it in, your pancakes will still be awesome. I use cake flour, but all-purpose works too. I'd suggest adding the flour little by little instead of dumping it all in at once. That way, the dough won't get too thick. We're aiming for a nice, creamy consistency. Now let's set this mix aside and give it some time. Next, let's dive into the whites. Grab your mixer and start whipping on low speed. If you want to whisk by hand, go for it, but it's going to be a workout. Once you see some foam, start adding the sugar bit by bit. Gradually crank up the mixer speed to high. Oh, and I almost forgot—it's a really good idea to pop the egg whites in the freezer for 10 to 15 minutes before you start whipping them. Cold egg whites trap air more effectively, which results in a fluffier, more stable meringue. Whip the egg whites until stiff peaks form, but don't go too far. Once they're shiny and can hold their shape, stop. I once messed up by whipping them too much, and the batter ended up too runny. We finally made it! Add about a third of the egg whites into the egg yolk mixture. Stir it well until smooth, but leave the mixer out of it. Drop a comment below and let me know which country you're watching from. Now pour this mixture into the rest of the egg whites. While you're at it, I'd love to hear your thoughts on how I can make my videos even better. Gently fold it all together with a spatula. Don't use a whisk or mixer—keeping it light and airy is key. This technique creates air pockets that make the pancakes rise to incredible heights when cooked. Let's grab a pastry bag. If you're feeling rebellious, you can totally skip it and just go without. Transfer the mixture into a pastry bag. If you don't have one, no worries—just use a regular bag and cut off a corner. Actually, you can just gently spoon the mixture if you prefer. Turn the stove to low heat. As you can see, I keep the flame super low so it doesn't go out. Give it a quick oiling. Getting the right heat is crucial for making Japanese pancakes. If it's too high, the pancakes will puff up fast but also deflate just as quickly once you take them out of the pan. Now gently squeeze the batter onto the preheated skillet. You'll notice it holds its shape and doesn't spread out. That's your meringue flexing its muscles,  showing it’s whipped to perfection! Let's pick up the pace and jump ahead. Add a few drops of water to the pan. This will create steam to help the pancakes stay moist. Cover with a lid and cook for 7 to 10 minutes. It should cook very low and slow. Try not to lift the lid. Nice job! Now let's flip these bad boys without making a mess. Honestly, I'm a bit nervous—I’ve had some epic fails before. If you like my video, don't forget to subscribe. Just under a million subscribers to get to a million! So far, so good. Let's toss in a few more drops of water, slap a lid on it, and let it cook for another 5 minutes or so. Getting pancakes fluffy takes a bit of effort. I had a few flops before nailing it, but even when they didn’t look perfect, they were still soft, tender, and tasty. From my experience, the secret to fluffy pancakes is whipping the meringue just right and cooking on low heat. Thanks for watching! See you later.
output:
**Japanese Soufflé Pancakes**

**Ingredients:**
* 2 large eggs, separated
* 2 tablespoons milk
* 1/4 teaspoon vanilla extract (optional)
* 1/4 cup (30g) cake flour or all-purpose flour
* 2 tablespoons granulated sugar
* Oil or butter, for greasing the pan
* Water, for steaming

**Instructions:**
1. Separate the egg yolks and whites. Place the egg whites in the freezer for 10-15 minutes to chill.
2. In a medium bowl, whisk the egg yolks with the milk and vanilla extract (if using) until smooth.
3. Sift the flour into the yolk mixture. Add it gradually, whisking until you achieve a smooth, creamy batter with no lumps. Set aside.
4. In a clean, dry bowl, beat the chilled egg whites with a mixer on low speed until foamy. Gradually add the sugar while increasing the mixer speed to high. Whip until stiff, glossy peaks form. Be careful not to over-whip.
5. Gently stir about one-third of the meringue into the yolk batter until fully incorporated and smooth.
6. Pour this mixture back into the remaining meringue. Using a spatula, gently fold everything together until just combined and no white streaks remain. Be careful not to deflate the batter.
7. Transfer the batter to a pastry bag or a large plastic bag with a corner snipped off.
8. Heat a non-stick skillet or griddle over very low heat. Lightly grease it with oil or butter.
9. Pipe tall, round mounds of batter onto the skillet. Add a few teaspoons of water around the pancakes, away from the batter.
10. Immediately cover the skillet with a lid. Cook for 7-10 minutes on low heat. Do not lift the lid.
11. Carefully flip each pancake using a spatula. Add another few drops of water to the pan, cover again, and cook for an additional 5 minutes.
12. Serve immediately.

**Tips:**
- Chilling the egg whites before whipping helps create a more stable and fluffy meringue.
- Folding the batter gently with a spatula (not a whisk) is crucial to maintaining the air pockets for a tall, fluffy rise.
- Cooking on very low heat is essential. High heat will cause the pancakes to rise quickly and then collapse.

**Classic Bruschetta**

**Ingredients:**
* 6 medium Roma tomatoes (about 1.5 lbs), cored and diced
* 1/3 cup fresh basil leaves, thinly sliced (chiffonade)
* 5 cloves garlic, finely minced (divided)
* 5 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil (divided)
* 1 tablespoon balsamic vinegar
* 1/2 teaspoon salt
* 1/4 teaspoon black pepper
* 1 long French baguette, cut into 1/2-inch diagonal slices
* 1/3 to 1/2 cup shredded Parmesan cheese

**Instructions:**
1. In a medium bowl, combine the diced tomatoes, sliced basil, and 4 cloves of the minced garlic.
2. Add 2 tablespoons of olive oil, the balsamic vinegar, salt, and pepper to the tomato mixture. Stir to combine and set aside to marinate for 15-30 minutes.
3. Preheat the oven to 400°F with a rack in the center position.
4. In a small bowl, combine the remaining 3 tablespoons of olive oil with the remaining 1 clove of minced garlic.
5. Arrange the baguette slices on a parchment-lined baking sheet. Brush both sides of each slice with the garlic-infused olive oil.
6. Sprinkle the shredded Parmesan cheese evenly over the oiled toasts.
7. Bake at 400°F for 5 minutes, then switch the oven to broil on high heat for 1-2 minutes, or until the edges are golden brown.
8. To serve, top each crisp toast with a generous spoonful of the marinated tomato mixture.

**Tips:**
- For the best flavor, use the highest quality, fresh ingredients you can find, especially the tomatoes, basil, and olive oil.
- To prevent crushing the delicate basil, stack the leaves, roll them tightly, and use a sharp knife to slice them thinly (chiffonade).
- For a party, keep the toasted bread and tomato mixture separate until serving so the bread stays crisp. Let guests assemble their own.
- For an extra flavor boost, drizzle assembled bruschetta with a little more extra virgin olive oil or a balsamic glaze just before serving.

**Fresh Spring Rolls with Peanut Sauce**

**Ingredients:**
*For the Rice Vermicelli:*
* 5–6 oz (140–170g) rice vermicelli noodles

*For the Peanut Sauce:*
* ½ cup (148g) hoisin sauce
* ¼ cup (60g) smooth peanut butter
* 1 tbsp (15g) sambal or chili paste
* 2 tbsp (28g) rice vinegar
* 2 cloves garlic, grated
* ¼ cup (60ml) warm water
* Toasted peanuts and crispy shallots (for garnish, optional)

*For the Crispy Shallots (Optional):*
* 6–8 shallots, peeled
* Vegetable oil for frying (enough for 1.5 inches in pan)

*For the Traditional Shrimp Filling:*
* 1 lb (450g) shrimp, peeled and deveined
* 1–2 carrots, julienned
* 1–2 Thai chilies, thinly sliced
* ¼ cup (5g) fresh mint, torn
* ¼ cup (5g) fresh cilantro, torn
* ¼ cup (6g) Thai basil, torn
* Zest of 1 lime
* Lettuce leaves (such as Boston or butter lettuce)
* 8–10 round rice paper sheets

*For the Spam Filling Variation:*
* 1 (12 oz) can Spam Classic
* 1 tbsp (14g) granulated sugar
* 1 tbsp (15ml) hot water
* 2 tbsp (30ml) lime juice
* 2 tbsp (30ml) fish sauce
* 2 cloves garlic, minced
* 2 Thai chilies, thinly sliced
* 1 cucumber
* Lettuce leaves
* Cooked rice vermicelli noodles
* Carrot herb salad (from shrimp filling ingredients)
* Crispy shallots
* Hoisin sauce (for glazing, optional)
* 8–10 round rice paper sheets

**Instructions:**
1. Prepare the rice vermicelli noodles according to package directions (typically boil for 6 minutes). Drain, plunge into an ice water bath until cold, rinse thoroughly, and set aside.
2. Make the peanut sauce: In a bowl, whisk together hoisin sauce, peanut butter, sambal, rice vinegar, and grated garlic. Thin with warm water until desired consistency is reached. Set aside.
3. For crispy shallots (optional): Thinly slice shallots (just under ¼ inch thick). Add to a deep pan with 1.5 inches of cold vegetable oil. Place over medium-high heat, stirring constantly with chopsticks. Fry until bubbling subsides and shallots turn golden brown. Immediately remove and drain on paper towels (they will continue to brown off heat). Let cool completely.
4. For the shrimp filling: Bring a medium pot of water to a boil (optional: add aromatics like shallot or ginger). Add shrimp, cover, and turn off heat. Let poach for 3–4 minutes. Remove shrimp and immediately transfer to an ice water bath to cool. Slice each shrimp in half lengthwise.
5. Prepare the carrot herb salad: In a medium bowl, combine julienned carrots, sliced Thai chilies, torn mint, cilantro, Thai basil, and lime zest. Toss to combine.
6. For the Spam variation: Slice Spam into ¼-inch slices, then cut slices into rectangles. Sear in a hot oiled pan over medium-high heat for 2 minutes per side until crispy. Optionally, brush with hoisin sauce after flipping and glaze with a kitchen torch. For the dressing, dissolve sugar in hot water, then whisk in lime juice, fish sauce, minced garlic, and sliced chilies. Adjust sweetness or acidity if needed. Use a mandolin or knife to shave the cucumber into long, thin ribbons.
7. Assemble the spring rolls: Fill a large bowl with warm water. Submerge one rice paper sheet for 2–3 seconds until pliable. Lay it flat on a cutting board.
   * For traditional shrimp: Layer lettuce, a small bundle of noodles, carrot herb salad, more lettuce, and shrimp halves (cut side up). Fold the right side over the filling, then the left side. Starting from the bottom, roll tightly upward.
   * For Spam variation: Lay 4 cucumber ribbons side-by-side across the center of the rice paper and press to adhere. Top with lettuce, noodles (lightly dressed with the Spam variation dressing), carrot herb salad, crispy shallots, and seared Spam. Fold and roll as above.
8. Repeat with remaining ingredients. Serve spring rolls immediately with peanut sauce, garnished with crushed toasted peanuts and crispy shallots if

output:
**Homemade Samosa Wrappers & Samosas**

**Ingredients:**
*   For the Dough:
    *   4 cups (500g) all-purpose flour, plus extra for dusting
    *   1 teaspoon kosher salt
    *   1/2 teaspoon sugar
    *   1 cup (240ml) water, as needed
    *   1 teaspoon olive oil, plus extra for brushing
*   For Assembly:
    *   Prepared samosa filling (e.g., spiced beef)
    *   2 tablespoons all-purpose flour, mixed with a little water to form a paste (or use egg wash)

**Instructions:**
1.  Make the dough: In a large bowl, whisk together the 4 cups of flour, salt, and sugar. Gradually add about half of the water, mixing with a spatula. Continue adding water a little at a time until a dough forms with a consistency similar to chapati dough—it should feel firm but pliable.
2.  Knead and rest: Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured surface and knead for a few minutes until smooth. It will feel stiff but will absorb moisture as it rests. If needed, add a few more drops of water. Knead until the dough springs back lightly when pressed. Coat the dough ball with 1 teaspoon of olive oil, place it in a bowl, cover, and let it rest for 30 minutes.
3.  Portion the dough: After resting, roll the dough into a long log. Cut it into approximately 15 equal-sized pieces. Roll each piece into a smooth ball. Cover the balls with plastic wrap and let them rest for 10 more minutes.
4.  Form dough stacks: Divide the rested balls into groups of five. On a floured surface, roll one ball into a 5-inch circle. Roll a second ball to the same size. Brush the top of the first circle lightly with olive oil, dust with flour, and place the second circle on top. Repeat this process—brushing with oil, dusting with flour, and stacking—until all five circles are in one stack. Gently press the stack to align the edges. Repeat with the remaining dough balls to create more stacks. Cover the stacks with plastic wrap.
5.  Roll out the stacks: Lightly dust your work surface. Take one stack and roll it out into a thin, large circle, about 14 inches in diameter.
6.  Partially cook the wraps: Heat a cast iron skillet or griddle over low-medium heat. Carefully transfer the rolled-out stack to the hot skillet. Cook for about 1-2 minutes until slight bubbles form and the bottom is set but has no color. Carefully flip it and cook the other side briefly just to set. Do not cook through or let it brown. Remove and repeat with the remaining stacks.
7.  Peel the wraps: While still warm, carefully peel the cooked stack apart into five individual, very thin sheets of dough. Work quickly as they dry out fast. Repeat with all stacks.
8.  Cut the wraps: Stack a few peeled sheets and trim the rough edges with a sharp knife. Cut the stack in half, then into quarters or thirds to create triangles or rectangles for samosa wrappers.
9.  Assemble the samosas: Take one wrapper shape. For a triangle, fold one corner most of the way to the center. Brush the edge with the flour paste. Bring the opposite corner over to overlap and press to seal, forming a cone. Fill the pocket with 1-2 tablespoons of filling. Brush the remaining top flap with paste and fold it over to seal completely, ensuring the edges are tight. Repeat with all wrappers and filling.
10. Fry the samosas: Heat oil in a deep pot to 350°F (175°C). Fry the samosas in batches for 3-4 minutes, turning occasionally, until golden brown and crispy. Drain on a paper towel-lined plate.

**Tips:**
- The dough should be firm; it will soften and absorb water as it rests. Only add extra water a few drops at a time if absolutely necessary after kneading.
- Work quickly when peeling and handling the cooked dough sheets, as they dry and become brittle.
- Ensure the samosas are tightly sealed so oil doesn't enter during frying.
- The thin dough sheets can be fried as-is to make crispy chips.

two main things flavor and texture. You've probably heard the saying fat is
flavor. Those little white fatty spots in meat are
called marbling. When steak cooks, that fat melts into the

every single type of steak that comes from a cow before we cook. It is very important

to add anywhere between 1 and $4 signs to show how expensive the steaks are here. I've broken down this cow into a few

flank and plate sections. Cuts that come from the round shank and brisket sections cannot

which can make it hard to cook both perfectly. The filet mignon and the
tenderloin both also come from the same section, but are highly overrated. Given how expensive these two cuts are, I
would suggest using your money to get something with more fat and therefore more
flavor. Tri tip can also be tasty and typically has
great marbling, but it's very tough and unforgiving if you overcook it. So I don't recommend this cut either. From the flank section comes the flank
steak, which is probably most recognizable as the beef that comes in your beef and

it properly and cook it through to medium, it's delicious. Last but not least, we have
the short plate section. My favorite steak from here being the skirt
steak, specifically the outside skirt, which is more tender than the inside. Later in this video, we will cook and cut a
skirt steak. And I really want to focus on the cutting
portion of that because despite this being one of my favorite steaks out there, I was

there's just one last step before cooking. Seasoning. And the best part is it's very
simple. You'll just season with a high quality salt
at least an hour before cooking your steak, if not overnight. This process is called dry
brining, and it's seasons. The whole steak, not just the very outside,
which is what happens if you only salt right before cooking. Dry brining allows the salt
to go into the meat so you get that flavor everywhere. You can also get creative with

and mushy and doesn't really have much color to it. But remember, this steak is cooked to

because there's so much fat on my picanha I'm going to start by just rendering off that

output:
**Perfect Steak Guide: Techniques & Cuts**

**Ingredients:**
* Steak of choice (such as ribeye, skirt, hanger, porterhouse, picanha, or chuck)
* High-quality salt (such as kosher salt)
* Freshly cracked black pepper
* High-smoke-point oil (such as avocado or canola oil, for searing)
* Unsalted butter (for butter basting, optional)
* Garlic cloves (for butter basting, optional)
* Fresh rosemary or thyme (for butter basting, optional)

**Instructions:**
1. **Select & Season:** Choose your steak based on thickness and desired cooking method. At least 1 hour (or up to overnight) before cooking, generously season the steak on all sides with salt. This process is called dry brining.
2. **Prepare Cooking Method:**
    * **For Grilling:** Light charcoal and let it burn until covered with white-gray ash and glowing red-hot. For a gas grill, preheat to high.
    * **For Searing:** Place a cast-iron or heavy skillet over high heat until very hot. Add a high-smoke-point oil.
    * **For Reverse Sear:** Preheat oven to 250°F (120°C). Place steak on a rack set in a baking sheet.
    * **For Sous Vide:** Set a precision cooker (immersion circulator) to your desired final doneness temperature (e.g., 130°F/54°C for medium-rare). Vacuum-seal the seasoned steak.
    * **For Broiling:** Position an oven rack 4-6 inches from the broiler element and preheat the broiler to high.
3. **Cook the Steak:**
    * **Grilling (Thick Steak like Ribeye):** Place steak over direct heat. Sear for 3-5 minutes per side until a crust forms. Move to indirect heat, cover the grill, and cook until the internal temperature is 10°F below your target (see Tips). Rest for 10 minutes.
    * **Grilling (Thin Steak like Skirt):** Cook over high direct heat for 2-3 minutes per side until well-charred. Rest for 5-10 minutes.
    * **Searing & Butter Basting:** Place steak in the hot, oiled pan. Press down to ensure contact. Sear for 3-4 minutes until a crust forms. Flip, reduce heat to medium, and add butter and aromatics (garlic, herbs). Tilt pan and spoon the foaming butter over the steak repeatedly for 1-2 minutes. Rest for 10 minutes.
    * **Reverse Sear:** Cook steak in the 250°F (120°C) oven until the internal temperature reaches about 125°F (52°C). Sear in a very hot, oiled skillet for 60-90 seconds per side to develop a crust. Rest for 10 minutes.
    * **Sous Vide:** Submerge the sealed steak in the water bath and cook for 1-4 hours. Remove, pat very dry. Sear in a scorching hot, oiled pan for 60 seconds per side. Rest for 5 minutes.
    * **Broiling:** Place steak on a sheet tray. Broil for 4-6 minutes per side, watching closely, until charred and cooked to desired doneness. Rest for 10 minutes.
4. **Rest & Slice:** Let the steak rest on a cutting board for 5-10 minutes after cooking. Before slicing, identify the direction of the muscle fibers (the grain). Always slice the steak **against the grain** for maximum tenderness.

**Tips:**
- Use an instant-read thermometer to ensure perfect doneness. Pull the steak from the heat when it is 5-10°F below your target temperature, as it will continue to cook while resting (carryover cooking).
- For doneness, aim for these final internal temperatures: Rare: 120-125°F (49-52°C), Medium-Rare: 130-135°F (54-57°C), Medium: 140-145°F (60-63°C).
- When grilling a steak with a thick fat cap (like a ribeye), start by placing the fat-cap edge down on the grill or pan to render and crisp the fat.
- For a quick marinade, place steak and marinade in a vacuum-sealer container, seal to remove air, and let sit for 15 minutes to rapidly infuse flavor.
- After slicing, drag the steak pieces through any juices left on the cutting board.

output:
**Perfect Vanilla Cake**

**Ingredients:**
* 2 ½ cups (280g) all-purpose flour
* 2 ¼ teaspoons baking powder
* ¾ teaspoon salt
* ¾ cup (170g) unsalted butter, room temperature
* 1 ⅔ cups (333g) granulated sugar
* 3 large eggs, room temperature
* 1 tablespoon (15ml) vanilla extract
* 1 cup buttermilk, room temperature
* Butter and parchment paper for pans
* Vanilla buttercream frosting (for assembly)

**Instructions:**
1. Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Grease two 8-inch round cake pans with butter and line the bottoms with parchment paper circles.
2. In a medium bowl, sift together the flour, baking powder, and salt. Whisk to combine and set aside.
3. In the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the paddle attachment, cream the room-temperature butter on medium speed until smooth.
4. With the mixer running, gradually add the granulated sugar. Increase speed to high and beat for 3 minutes until light and fluffy. Stop to scrape down the bowl and paddle halfway through to ensure a homogenous mixture.
5. Reduce speed to medium. Add the eggs one at a time, allowing each to fully incorporate before adding the next.
6. Mix in the vanilla extract. Scrape down the bowl once more.
7. With the mixer on its lowest speed, add the dry ingredients and buttermilk in three alternating additions, beginning and ending with the dry ingredients. Mix only until almost combined; small streaks of flour are okay.
8. Finish mixing the batter by hand with a spatula until just combined and no dry pockets remain. Do not overmix.
9. Divide the batter evenly between the prepared pans (about 600g per pan). Tap the pans firmly on the counter to release large air bubbles.
10. Bake for about 30 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean. For flatter layers, use cake strips around the pans.
11. Let the cakes cool in the pans for 10 minutes, then turn out onto a wire rack to cool completely before frosting.
12. To assemble, place one cake layer on a plate or cake stand. Cover with a generous layer of vanilla buttercream. Top with the second layer.
13. Apply a thin crumb coat of frosting over the entire cake and smooth. Chill briefly if needed, then apply a final, thicker layer of frosting and smooth or decorate as desired.

**Tips:**
- For best results, measure flour by weight. If using cups, fluff the flour first, then spoon it into the measuring cup and level it off.
- Using room-temperature ingredients (butter, eggs, buttermilk) ensures the batter mixes evenly and bakes into a flat, tender cake without burnt edges.
- Avoid overmixing the batter once the flour is added to prevent developing gluten, which can make the cake tough and gummy.
- Press air bubbles out of your buttercream with a spatula before decorating for a smoother finish.

Making these pancakes fluffy might seem like rocket science, but don't sweat it. I've got all the tricks up my sleeve, and I'm spilling them in this video. Don't go anywhere unless you're heading out for eggs. Throw a splash of milk into the yolks. Milk helps to create a lighter, fluffier texture by adding moisture and contributing to the overall batter consistency. Adding vanilla extract would be a great touch; just make sure you don't accidentally use soy sauce instead. Unless you're feeling adventurous and really into unique flavors. Alright, let's add the flour. I'm a sifting nerd, but if you just dump it in, your pancakes will still be awesome. I use cake flour, but all-purpose works too. I'd suggest adding the flour little by little instead of dumping it all in at once. That way, the dough won't get too thick. We're aiming for a nice, creamy consistency. Now let's set this mix aside and give it some time. Next, let's dive into the whites. Grab your mixer and start whipping on low speed. If you want to whisk by hand, go for it, but it's going to be a workout. Once you see some foam, start adding the sugar bit by bit. Gradually crank up the mixer speed to high. Oh, and I almost forgot—it's a really good idea to pop the egg whites in the freezer for 10 to 15 minutes before you start whipping them. Cold egg whites trap air more effectively, which results in a fluffier, more stable meringue. Whip the egg whites until stiff peaks form, but don't go too far. Once they're shiny and can hold their shape, stop. I once messed up by whipping them too much, and the batter ended up too runny. We finally made it! Add about a third of the egg whites into the egg yolk mixture. Stir it well until smooth, but leave the mixer out of it. Drop a comment below and let me know which country you're watching from. Now pour this mixture into the rest of the egg whites. While you're at it, I'd love to hear your thoughts on how I can make my videos even better. Gently fold it all together with a spatula. Don't use a whisk or mixer—keeping it light and airy is key. This technique creates air pockets that make the pancakes rise to incredible heights when cooked. Let's grab a pastry bag. If you're feeling rebellious, you can totally skip it and just go without. Transfer the mixture into a pastry bag. If you don't have one, no worries—just use a regular bag and cut off a corner. Actually, you can just gently spoon the mixture if you prefer. Turn the stove to low heat. As you can see, I keep the flame super low so it doesn't go out. Give it a quick oiling. Getting the right heat is crucial for making Japanese pancakes. If it's too high, the pancakes will puff up fast but also deflate just as quickly once you take them out of the pan. Now gently squeeze the batter onto the preheated skillet. You'll notice it holds its shape and doesn't spread out. That's your meringue flexing its muscles,  showing it’s whipped to perfection! Let's pick up the pace and jump ahead. Add a few drops of water to the pan. This will create steam to help the pancakes stay moist. Cover with a lid and cook for 7 to 10 minutes. It should cook very low and slow. Try not to lift the lid. Nice job! Now let's flip these bad boys without making a mess. Honestly, I'm a bit nervous—I’ve had some epic fails before. If you like my video, don't forget to subscribe. Just under a million subscribers to get to a million! So far, so good. Let's toss in a few more drops of water, slap a lid on it, and let it cook for another 5 minutes or so. Getting pancakes fluffy takes a bit of effort. I had a few flops before nailing it, but even when they didn’t look perfect, they were still soft, tender, and tasty. From my experience, the secret to fluffy pancakes is whipping the meringue just right and cooking on low heat. Thanks for watching! See you later.
output:
**Japanese Soufflé Pancakes**

**Ingredients:**
* 2 large eggs, separated
* 2 tablespoons whole milk
* 1/4 teaspoon vanilla extract (optional)
* 1/4 cup (30g) cake flour or all-purpose flour
* 2 tablespoons granulated sugar
* Neutral oil (for greasing)
* 1-2 tablespoons water (for steaming)

**Instructions:**
1. Separate the egg yolks and whites. Place the egg whites in the freezer for 10-15 minutes to chill.
2. In a medium bowl, whisk the egg yolks with the milk and vanilla extract (if using) until smooth.
3. Sift the flour into the yolk mixture. Add it gradually, whisking until you achieve a smooth, creamy batter with no lumps. Set aside.
4. In a clean, dry bowl, use a hand mixer to whip the chilled egg whites on low speed until foamy. Gradually add the sugar while increasing the mixer speed to high. Whip until stiff, glossy peaks form. Be careful not to overwhip.
5. Gently stir about one-third of the meringue into the yolk batter until fully incorporated and smooth.
6. Pour this mixture back into the remaining meringue. Using a spatula, gently fold everything together until just combined and no white streaks remain. Be careful to preserve the air bubbles.
7. Transfer the batter to a pastry bag or a large plastic bag with a corner snipped off.
8. Heat a non-stick skillet or griddle over very low heat. Lightly grease it with oil.
9. Pipe tall, round mounds of batter onto the skillet. They should hold their shape without spreading.
10. Add a few drops of water to the pan around the pancakes, then immediately cover with a lid. Cook for 7-10 minutes. Do not lift the lid.
11. Carefully flip each pancake. Add another few drops of water to the pan, cover again, and cook for an additional 5 minutes.
12. Serve immediately.

**Tips:**
* Chilling the egg whites before whipping helps create a more stable and fluffy meringue.
* Folding the batter gently with a spatula (not a whisk) is crucial for maintaining air pockets and achieving maximum height.
* Cooking on very low heat is essential. High heat will cause the pancakes to rise quickly but collapse just as fast.

**BRUSCHETTA**

**Ingredients:**
* 6 medium Roma tomatoes (about 1.5 lbs), cored and diced
* 1/3 cup fresh basil leaves, thinly sliced (chiffonade)
* 5 cloves garlic, finely minced (divided)
* 5 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil (divided)
* 1 tablespoon balsamic vinegar
* 1/2 teaspoon salt
* 1/4 teaspoon black pepper
* 1 long French baguette, cut into 1/2-inch diagonal slices
* 1/3 to 1/2 cup shredded Parmesan cheese
* Balsamic glaze, for garnish (optional)

**Instructions:**
1. In a medium bowl, combine the diced tomatoes, sliced basil, 4 cloves of the minced garlic, 2 tablespoons of olive oil, balsamic vinegar, salt, and pepper. Stir to combine and set aside to marinate for 15-30 minutes.
2. In a small bowl, combine the remaining 1 clove of minced garlic with 3 tablespoons of olive oil to create a garlic-infused oil. Set aside.
3. Preheat your oven to 400°F with a rack in the center. Line a baking sheet with parchment paper.
4. Arrange the baguette slices on the prepared baking sheet. Brush both sides of each slice generously with the garlic-infused olive oil.
5. Sprinkle the shredded Parmesan cheese evenly over the top of each oiled slice.
6. Bake at 400°F for 5 minutes, then switch the oven to broil on high heat for 1-2 minutes, or until the edges are golden brown. Watch carefully to avoid burning.
7. To serve, top each crispy toast slice with a generous spoonful of the marinated tomato mixture. Optionally, drizzle with a little extra olive oil or balsamic glaze as a garnish.

**Tips:**
- For the best flavor, use the highest quality, fresh ingredients you can find, especially the tomatoes, basil, and olive oil.
- To prevent crushing the delicate basil, stack the leaves, roll them tightly, and use a sharp knife to thinly slice them into ribbons (chiffonade).
- For a party, keep the toasted bread and tomato mixture separate until serving so the bread stays crisp. Let guests assemble their own bruschetta.

output:
**Fresh Spring Rolls with Peanut Sauce**

**Ingredients:**
*For the Rice Vermicelli:*
* 5–6 ounces rice vermicelli noodles

*For the Peanut Sauce:*
* ½ cup (148 grams) hoisin sauce
* ¼ cup (60 grams) smooth peanut butter
* 1 tablespoon (15 grams) sambal or chili paste
* 2 tablespoons (28 grams) rice vinegar
* 2 cloves garlic, grated
* ¼ cup (60 milliliters) warm water

*For the Crispy Shallots (Optional Garnish):*
* 6–8 shallots, peeled
* Vegetable oil for frying (enough for 1.5 inches in a pan)
* 2 tablespoons toasted peanuts

*For the Traditional Shrimp Filling:*
* 1 pound shrimp, peeled and deveined
* 1–2 carrots, julienned
* 1–2 Thai chilies, thinly sliced
* ¼ cup (5 grams) fresh mint, torn
* ¼ cup (5 grams) fresh cilantro, torn
* ¼ cup (6 grams) Thai basil, torn
* Zest of 1 lime
* Lettuce leaves (such as Boston or butter lettuce)
* 8–10 round rice paper sheets

*For the Spam Filling Variation:*
* 1 (12-ounce) can Spam Classic, sliced into ¼-inch rectangles
* 1 tablespoon (14 grams) granulated sugar
* 1 tablespoon (15 milliliters) hot water
* 2 tablespoons (30 milliliters) lime juice
* 2 tablespoons (30 milliliters) fish sauce
* 2 cloves garlic, minced
* 2 Thai chilies, thinly sliced
* 1 cucumber, shaved into ribbons
* Lettuce leaves
* Rice vermicelli noodles (from above)
* Carrot herb salad (from above)
* Crispy shallots (from above)
* 8–10 round rice paper sheets
* Hoisin sauce (for optional glaze)
* Vegetable oil (for searing)

**Instructions:**
1. Prepare the rice vermicelli noodles according to package directions (typically boil for 6 minutes). Drain, plunge into an ice water bath until cold, rinse thoroughly, and set aside.
2. Make the peanut sauce: In a bowl, whisk together the hoisin sauce, peanut butter, sambal, rice vinegar, grated garlic, and warm water until smooth. Set aside.
3. For the crispy shallots (optional): Thinly slice the shallots (just under ¼-inch thick). Add oil to a deep pan to a depth of 1.5 inches. Add the shallots to the cold oil. Heat over medium-high heat, stirring constantly with chopsticks. Fry until the bubbling subsides and they turn light golden brown. Immediately remove and drain on a paper towel (they will continue to brown). Let cool completely. For a garnish, crush a handful of the cooled shallots with toasted peanuts and sprinkle over the peanut sauce when serving.
4. For the shrimp filling: Bring a medium pot of water to a boil. Optionally add aromatics like shallot or ginger. Add the shrimp, cover, and turn off the heat. Let poach for 3–4 minutes. Remove and immediately transfer to an ice water bath to cool. Slice each shrimp in half lengthwise.
5. Prepare the carrot herb salad: In a medium bowl, combine the julienned carrots, sliced Thai chilies, torn mint, cilantro, Thai basil, and lime zest. Toss to combine.
6. Assemble the traditional shrimp spring rolls: Fill a large bowl with warm water. Submerge one rice paper sheet for 2–3 seconds until pliable. Lay it flat on a cutting board. Layer with lettuce, a small bundle of rice noodles, carrot herb salad, more lettuce, and 2–3 shrimp halves (arranged cut-side up). Fold the right side over the filling, then the left side. Starting from the bottom, roll tightly upward to seal. Repeat with remaining ingredients.
7. For the Spam variation: Heat oil in a medium pan over medium-high heat. Sear Spam slices in batches for about 2 minutes per side until crispy. Optionally, brush the seared side with hoisin sauce and brulee with a kitchen torch for a glaze. Set aside.
8. Make the *nước chấm* dressing: Dissolve the sugar in hot water. Whisk in lime juice, fish sauce, minced garlic, and sliced Thai chilies. Adjust sweetness or acidity if needed.
9. Assemble the Spam spring rolls: Rehydrate a rice paper sheet as in step 6. Lay it flat and shingle 4 cucumber ribbons across the center, pressing to adhere. Top

output:
**Homemade Samosa Wrappers & Samosas**

**Ingredients:**
*   For the Wrappers:
    *   4 cups (500g) all-purpose flour, plus extra for dusting
    *   1 teaspoon kosher salt
    *   1/2 teaspoon sugar
    *   1 cup (240ml) water, as needed
    *   1 teaspoon olive oil, plus extra for brushing
*   For Assembly:
    *   Prepared samosa filling (e.g., spiced beef)
    *   2 tablespoons all-purpose flour, mixed with a little water to form a paste (or use egg wash)

**Instructions:**
1.  Make the dough: In a large bowl, whisk together the 4 cups of flour, salt, and sugar. Gradually add most of the water, mixing with a spatula until a shaggy dough forms. Add the remaining water only if needed.
2.  Knead the dough: Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured surface and knead until smooth and it springs back when poked, about 5-7 minutes. The consistency should be similar to chapati dough (firm but pliable).
3.  Rest the dough: Drizzle the teaspoon of olive oil over the dough, shape it into a ball, place it back in the bowl, cover, and let it rest for 30 minutes.
4.  Portion the dough: After resting, roll the dough into a long log. Cut it into approximately 15 equal pieces and roll each into a smooth ball. Cover the balls and let them rest for 10 more minutes.
5.  Form dough stacks: Divide the balls into groups of five. On a floured surface, roll one ball into a 5-inch circle. Brush the top lightly with olive oil and dust with flour. Roll a second ball to the same size and place it directly on top of the first. Repeat the oil, flour, and stacking process until you have a stack of five circles. Press the stack gently to seal the edges. Repeat with the remaining dough balls to create more stacks. Cover the stacks with plastic wrap.
6.  Roll the stacks: Lightly flour your work surface. Take one stack and roll it out into a thin, 14-inch circle, dusting with flour as needed to prevent sticking.
7.  Partially cook the wraps: Heat a cast iron skillet or griddle over low-medium heat. Carefully transfer the large, thin circle to the hot skillet. Cook for about 1-2 minutes until slight bubbles form and the bottom is dry but not colored. Carefully flip it and cook the other side briefly, just until set. Remove and repeat with the remaining stacks.
8.  Peel the wraps: While still warm, carefully peel the cooked stack apart into five individual, very thin wrappers. Work quickly to prevent them from drying out.
9.  Cut the wrappers: Stack a few wrappers and trim the rough edges with a sharp knife. Cut the stack in half, then into quarters or thirds to create triangles or rectangles for samosas or spring rolls.
10. Fill and shape the samosas: Place a wrapper triangle with the point facing you. Fold the right corner over towards the center. Brush the folded edge with the flour paste. Bring the left corner over to completely cover the right flap, pressing to seal and form a cone. Hold the cone open, fill it with 1-2 tablespoons of filling, then fold the top flap down and seal with more paste. Ensure the seal is tight.
11. Fry the samosas: Heat oil in a deep pot to 350°F (175°C). Fry the samosas in batches for 3-4 minutes, turning occasionally, until golden brown and crispy. Drain on a paper towel-lined plate.

**Tips:**
- The dough should be firm; it will soften as it rests. Only add a few extra drops of water while kneading if absolutely necessary.
- Work quickly when peeling and handling the cooked wrappers, as they dry out fast due to their thinness.
- For a tight seal when shaping samosas, ensure no filling gets on the edges where you apply the paste. A tight seal prevents oil from seeping in during frying.
- The thin wrappers can also be cut and fried on their own to make crispy chips.

- Hey, I'm John Kanell.
Today on "Preppy Kitchen" we're making a quick and
easy, super creamy hummus, so let's get started. The best way to cook your hummus is gonna be from chickpeas
you cook at home, but if you want to use canned chickpeas, I have a great hack for you. The problem with canned

adding a clove of garlic. You could add more than one clove. You could roast the garlic, and really, you could add so
many different flavors in here. One nice clove. For some contrast, I'm adding
half a teaspoon of salt. You could add more if
you like it extra salty, and half a teaspoon of cumin. When I was in my twenties, my go to appetizer whenever
I had people over was hummus. And I would make a batch from scratch, but I would add in like
two to three jalapenos and a giant fistful of cilantro. (John smacks lips) So good. Just add it in the food processor kind of towards the end. It'll chop up into little
pieces and be spicy and amazing. Any herb will work well in this though. Get it started and let the
food processor do the work. Your mixer is gonna be
working for a while, so you can walk away and come
back or keep an eye on it, it's up to you. You do want to have some ice water on hand because we'll be drizzling
in two tablespoons in a few minutes. And by the way, if you're wondering where the word hummus comes from, it means chickpea in Arabic. Hmm. (processor whirring) This is a great time
to scrape the bowl down because it's looking fairly smooth, but there's nonsense all up
on this bowl, so pat it down. This is actually a great science lesson because even though all
my ingredients were cold, after this is done, the
hummus itself is gonna be warm from all the kinetic
energy of that blade moving in the food processor. My hummus looks fairly smooth, so it's time to add in about two table... About two tablespoons of ice water. The ice water is gonna help
the ingredients emulsify, and we're adding water in the first place because the hummus is
pretty thick right now. If you wanted to, you
could add more lemon juice for a really lemony kick though. One and two. I'm gonna let the...
(processor whirring) I'm gonna let the food processor run for about five minutes. It might seem like a lot, but you want that humus
to be so nice and creamy. While your processor is running, think about whether you want this plain, if you wanna divide it in
batches and add extra flavors, or if you wanna like scavenge
the fridge for inspiration, the world is your oyster. (processor whirring) If you want more hummus, just
double or triple this recipe. It is so easy as long
as your food processor can handle the extra ingredients. Three minutes in, you're gonna
wanna scrape the bowl down. Just tamp everything down. You can also look right in the middle and scooch away any liquid if
there's a little pool there. Add in one tablespoon of
extra virgin olive oil. Let this mixer run and you're gonna notice it is actually pretty warm,
all that kinetic energy. And just like that, our hummus is done. Now it's ready to garnish. Paprika, sumac, za'atar,
roasted pine nuts, roasted garlic, more chickpeas. There are so many different
types of garnishes you can do, and it's really whatever
flavors you'd like to use. It really comes down to
what you have on hand and what flavors you want to use. Today. I'm keeping it simple with some minced parsley and paprika. If stored in an airtight container, your hummus will last for
up to a week in the fridge. You could use it in dips and spreads. It's great in falafels, and it's honestly
delicious by the spoonful. Garnish with a really nice olive oil add a sprinkle of paprika or sumac. Your hummus is officially ready to enjoy. Hmm, creamy and substantial with a lovely kiss of lemon and garlic. It is just about perfect. I hope you get a chance
to make this recipe. And if you liked this video,

output:
**Creamy Homemade Hummus**

**Ingredients:**
* 1 (15-ounce) can chickpeas, drained and rinsed
* 1/4 cup tahini, well-stirred
* 3-4 tablespoons fresh lemon juice
* 1 clove garlic
* 1/2 teaspoon salt
* 1/2 teaspoon ground cumin
* 2 tablespoons ice water
* 1 tablespoon extra virgin olive oil, plus more for garnish
* Paprika, sumac, za'atar, or minced parsley for garnish (optional)

**Instructions:**
1. For a creamier texture (optional): Place the drained chickpeas in a small pot and cover with 2 inches of water. Simmer for 20 minutes until the skins float to the top. Skim off and discard the skins, then drain and rinse the chickpeas.
2. In a food processor, combine the prepared chickpeas, tahini, lemon juice, garlic, salt, and cumin.
3. Process the mixture until it is fairly smooth, about 2-3 minutes. Stop to scrape down the sides of the bowl as needed.
4. With the processor running, slowly drizzle in the 2 tablespoons of ice water. Continue to process for a full 5 minutes until very creamy and smooth, stopping once to scrape down the bowl again.
5. While the processor is still running, add the 1 tablespoon of olive oil and process until fully incorporated.
6. Transfer the hummus to a serving bowl. Garnish with a drizzle of olive oil and a sprinkle of paprika, sumac, za'atar, or minced parsley, if desired.

**Tips:**
- For a flavor variation, try adding roasted garlic, jalapeños, cilantro, or other herbs by pulsing them in at the end of processing.
- The hummus will be warm from the friction of the food processor blade but will firm up when chilled.
- Store in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to one week.

output:
**Guacamole**

**Ingredients:**
* 3 ripe Hass avocados
* 1/2 medium white onion, finely diced
* 1-2 serrano peppers, finely diced (seeds in for more heat)
* 1/4 cup fresh cilantro, chopped (plus more for garnish)
* 2-3 plum tomatoes, seeded and diced
* 2-3 limes, juiced (to taste)
* Salt, to taste
* Queso fresco, for garnish (optional)

**Instructions:**
1. Select ripe avocados by checking the color (dark green, not bright green or black) and the stem spot (it should be greenish-yellow when removed).
2. Cut each avocado in half around the pit. Twist to separate the halves. Carefully remove the pit by tapping it with a chef's knife and twisting it out.
3. Dice the avocado flesh in the skin using a small knife, then scoop it out into a molcajete (or a large bowl).
4. Finely dice the onion, serrano peppers, and cilantro. Add them to the molcajete.
5. Squeeze in the juice of 1-2 limes over the onion mixture.
6. Using the pestle of the molcajete (or a wooden spoon), smash and grind the onion, serrano, cilantro, and lime juice into a coarse paste. This releases and blends the flavors.
7. Add the diced avocado and a generous pinch of salt to the molcajete. Gently mash and fold the ingredients together until combined but still chunky. Avoid over-mashing into a puree.
8. Gently fold in the diced tomatoes last to prevent the guacamole from becoming watery.
9. Taste and adjust seasoning with more salt and lime juice as needed.
10. Garnish with additional cilantro and crumbled queso fresco, if desired. Serve immediately with sturdy corn tortilla chips.

**Tips:**
- Pre-dicing the avocado in the skin makes it easier to mash later.
- To get more juice from a lime, roll it firmly on the counter before cutting and juicing.
- For a smoother guacamole without chunks of onion or pepper, ensure they are diced very finely before smashing into a paste.
- Serve the guacamole in a cold molcajete or bowl to keep it fresh longer.

In grocery stores, you'll find it numbered 1, 2, 3, and 4, you want fine bulgur, which is number 1. This is what you want, and normally, the way you would cook this, to use it, just put it in some water, and it'll absorb the

What's gonna happen is, after about 10, 15 minutes, the bulgur is going to absorb all that lemon juice and the olive oil, and that's going to be the base for the salad vinegarette. output:
**Traditional Lebanese Tabbouleh**

**Ingredients:**
* 2 bunches fresh parsley, finely chopped (about 2 cups chopped)
* 1/4 cup fine bulgur wheat (#1)
* 1/3 cup extra virgin olive oil
* 3-4 tablespoons fresh lemon juice, plus extra for adjusting and slices for garnish
* 2-3 medium tomatoes
* 3 green onions, finely chopped
* 3 tablespoons fresh mint, finely chopped (optional)
* Salt and black pepper, to taste

**Instructions:**
1. In a small bowl, combine the fine bulgur wheat with 3 tablespoons of lemon juice and the 1/3 cup of olive oil. Stir with a fork and let it soak for 10-15 minutes until the bulgur has absorbed the liquid and softened.
2. Finely chop the parsley by hand (do not use a food processor). Transfer it to a large serving bowl.
3. Add the chopped mint (if using) and chopped green onions to the parsley.
4. Prepare the tomatoes: quarter them, remove and discard the seeds and juicy pulp, leaving only the firm flesh. Finely chop the firm tomato flesh. You should have about 1/2 cup, which is roughly one-quarter the volume of the parsley.
5. Add the chopped tomatoes to the bowl. Season generously with salt and pepper, tossing to coat the tomatoes.
6. Pour the soaked bulgur mixture (including all the liquid) into the bowl with the vegetables. Gently mix everything together until well combined.
7. Taste and adjust seasoning, adding more salt, pepper, or lemon juice as desired.
8. Garnish with reserved chopped tomato and lemon slices before serving.

**Tips:**
- Use the finest grade of bulgur wheat (#1) for the most authentic texture.
- Hand-chopping the parsley, while labor-intensive, provides a superior texture and flavor compared to using a food processor.
- Removing the seeds and pulp from the tomatoes prevents the salad from becoming watery.

output:
**Gazpacho**

**Ingredients:**
* 1 ½ lbs vine-ripe tomatoes, concassé (peeled, seeded, and chopped)
* 1 cup cucumber, peeled, seeded, and chopped
* ½ cup red onion, chopped
* ½ cup red bell pepper, diced
* 1 jalapeño, seeded and minced
* 1 clove garlic, minced
* 1 cup tomato juice (reserved from concassé)
* ¼ cup extra virgin olive oil
* Juice of 1 lime
* 2 tsp balsamic vinegar
* 2 tsp Worcestershire sauce
* 1 tsp kosher salt
* ½ tsp cumin, roasted and ground
* ¼ tsp black pepper
* Basil chiffonade, for garnish

**Instructions:**
1. Prepare all vegetables: concassé the tomatoes, peel and chop the cucumber, chop the red onion, dice the red bell pepper, and mince the jalapeño and garlic.
2. In a large bowl, combine the prepared tomatoes, cucumber, red onion, bell pepper, jalapeño, garlic, and tomato juice. Stir to mix.
3. Add the olive oil, lime juice, balsamic vinegar, Worcestershire sauce, kosher salt, ground cumin, and black pepper to the bowl. Stir thoroughly until well combined.
4. Transfer about 1 ½ cups of the mixture to a blender and liquefy until smooth.
5. Pour the blended mixture back into the bowl with the remaining chunky mixture and stir to incorporate.
6. Refrigerate the gazpacho for at least a few hours to chill and allow the flavors to meld.
7. Before serving, garnish with a basil chiffonade.

**Tips:**
- Reserve the juice from concasséing the tomatoes to use as the tomato juice in the recipe.
- For the best flavor, use roasted and freshly ground cumin.

output:
**Overnight French Toast**

**Ingredients:**
* 1 cup half-and-half
* 2 tablespoons honey
* 3 large eggs
* 1/4 teaspoon salt
* 8-10 slices of bread (such as brioche or challah), left out to stale for at least 8 hours
* Butter, for cooking

**Instructions:**
1. The night before, make the custard. In a medium bowl, gently whisk together the half-and-half, honey, eggs, and salt until just combined. Cover the bowl and refrigerate overnight.
2. Also the night before, arrange your bread slices on a rack or plate to stale and dry out for at least 8 hours.
3. In the morning, preheat your oven to 375°F (190°C) and place a rack in the upper-middle position. Set a wire cooling rack inside a rimmed baking sheet.
4. Pour the chilled custard into a pie plate or shallow dish. Soak two slices of dried bread for 30 seconds per side, then transfer them to a clean plate to rest for 2 minutes, allowing the custard to absorb fully.
5. While the first slices rest, heat a large non-stick skillet over medium-low heat (approx. 350-375°F / 175-190°C). Add enough butter to lightly coat the bottom.
6. When the butter begins to bubble, add the rested bread slices. Cook for 5-10 minutes total, until golden brown on both sides. Transfer the cooked toast to the prepared wire rack.
7. While the first batch cooks, repeat steps 4 and 5 with the remaining bread, working in batches of two slices.
8. Once all slices are browned, transfer the entire baking sheet with the wire rack to the preheated oven. Bake for 5 minutes to set the custard and ensure a creamy interior.

**Tips:**
- For a smoother custard, especially for guests, strain the mixture through a fine-mesh sieve before refrigerating to remove any chalazae (egg white strands).
- Using thoroughly dried, stale bread is critical. It absorbs the custard without falling apart, resulting in a sturdy slice with a creamy center.

input: Cinnamon rolls this good shouldn't even be possible. And yet, here we are. As a first step, we need to bloom our yeast. Right here, I have some active dry yeast, which I'm going to combine with some warm milk. Give it a quick whisk, and then let that sit for 10 minutes to make sure it foams up and is alive, just like this one here. Next, grab the bowl of your stand mixer and add in your flour, sugar, and salt, which we're going to quickly whisk before locking back into the stand mixer. Next, we'll combine a couple eggs as well as our yeast mixture into a bowl. Whoa, it made a perfect X. And then whisk this up until fully combined. Now, we'll add our egg mixture into our flour mixture. And then mix on medium until everything has formed into a dough. Scraping down the sides of your bowl with a rubber spatula as needed. When it's done, it'll look something like this. Not the best looking dough yet, but remember, we still have to add the best part, the butter. We'll bring our mixer back up to medium speed and add in our room temperature butter. output:
**Brown Butter Cinnamon Rolls with Candied Walnuts**

**Ingredients:**
*For the Dough:*
* 1 cup warm whole milk (about 110°F)
* 2 ¼ teaspoons active dry yeast (1 packet)
* 4 ½ cups all-purpose flour, plus more for dusting
* ⅓ cup granulated sugar
* 1 teaspoon salt
* 2 large eggs
* ½ cup (1 stick) unsalted butter, room temperature, cubed

*For the Brown Butter Filling:*
* ½ cup (1 stick) unsalted butter
* ¾ cup packed light brown sugar
* 2 tablespoons honey
* 2 tablespoons ground cinnamon
* ¼ teaspoon freshly grated nutmeg
* ¼ teaspoon salt
* 1 large egg

*For Assembly & Baking:*
* ¼ cup heavy cream
* Cooking spray or butter for greasing

*For the Candied Walnuts:*
* 2 tablespoons unsalted butter
* ¼ cup packed light brown sugar
* Pinch of salt
* 1 cup walnut halves
* Zest of ½ lemon

*For the Cream Cheese Frosting:*
* 4 ounces cream cheese, room temperature
* ¼ cup (½ stick) unsalted butter, room temperature
* 1 cup powdered sugar
* 1 tablespoon milk or cream
* 1 teaspoon vanilla extract
* 1 teaspoon lemon juice

**Instructions:**
1. **Bloom the yeast:** In a small bowl, whisk the warm milk and active dry yeast together. Let sit for 10 minutes until foamy.
2. **Make the dough base:** In the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with the dough hook, whisk together the flour, granulated sugar, and salt.
3. **Combine wet ingredients:** In a separate bowl, whisk the 2 eggs with the foamy yeast mixture until combined. With the mixer on low, pour the egg mixture into the flour mixture. Mix on medium speed until a shaggy dough forms, scraping the bowl as needed.
4. **Incorporate the butter:** With the mixer running on medium speed, add the room-temperature butter cubes one or two at a time, waiting until each is fully incorporated before adding the next. This should take 5-7 minutes.
5. **Knead the dough:** Increase the mixer speed to medium-high (about 6) and knead until the dough is smooth, elastic, and passes the "windowpane test" (a small piece can be stretched thin enough to see light through it without tearing), about 5-8 minutes.
6. **First rise:** Butter a large glass bowl. Shape the dough into a ball, place it in the bowl, and cover with plastic wrap. Let rise at room temperature until doubled in size, 1 ½ to 2 hours.
7. **Chill the dough:** Punch down the dough to release air. Re-cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate overnight.
8. **Make the brown butter filling:** While the dough chills, melt the ½ cup butter in a saucepan over medium heat. Cook, stirring constantly and scraping the sides, until the butter foams and turns golden brown with a nutty aroma. Immediately pour into a room-temperature bowl to stop cooking. Let cool slightly, then whisk in the brown sugar, honey, cinnamon, nutmeg, and salt. Let the mixture cool to room temperature.
9. **Finish the filling:** Using a stand mixer with the whisk attachment, beat the brown butter mixture on medium speed until it becomes frosting-like, light in color, and doubled in volume, about 3-4 minutes. Scrape the bowl. Add the 1 egg and mix on medium-high until fully incorporated and the mixture resembles a thick frosting. Set aside at room temperature.
10. **Shape the rolls:** On a floured surface, roll the chilled dough into a 12x16-inch rectangle. Dust off any excess flour. Spread the brown butter filling evenly over the dough, leaving a ½-inch border along the long edge closest to you.
11. **Roll and chill:** Starting from the long edge with filling, tightly roll the dough into a log. Trim off the uneven ends. Wrap the log tightly in parchment paper and then plastic wrap. Freeze for at least 20 minutes to firm up.
12. **Cut and proof:** Unwrap the log. Using a sharp, thin knife, cut it into 10 even pieces. Grease a baking dish and line with parchment paper. Arrange the rolls in the dish, spacing them apart. Cover with plastic wrap and let proof at room temperature until doubled in size, about 1 ½ hours.
13. **Bake:** Preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Once proofed, spoon 1 teaspoon of heavy cream

output:
**Josh’s Ultimate Chocolate Chip Cookies**

**Ingredients:**
* ½ cup (100g) granulated sugar
* ¾ cup (150g) light brown sugar, packed
* ½ cup (113g) unsalted butter, melted and cooled slightly
* 1 large egg
* 1 large egg yolk
* 1 tsp kosher salt (or ¾ tsp fine sea salt)
* ½ tsp baking soda
* 2 tsp vanilla extract
* 1 cup plus 6 tbsp (175g) all-purpose flour
* 3 oz (85g) dark chocolate (60-70% cacao), roughly chopped
* 3 oz (85g) milk chocolate, roughly chopped
* ½ cup (15g) plain salted kettle-cooked potato chips, crushed by hand

**Instructions:**
1. Roughly chop the dark and milk chocolate, leaving any fine chocolate "dust" from chopping.
2. In a large bowl, whisk together the granulated sugar and light brown sugar until no lumps remain.
3. Add the melted butter and whisk vigorously until fully combined.
4. Add the whole egg and whisk until the mixture is creamy and emulsified (no oil separation).
5. Carefully separate the egg yolk and add it to the bowl. Whisk again until fully incorporated and emulsified.
6. Whisk in the kosher salt, baking soda, and vanilla extract.
7. Add half of the flour and gently fold with a rubber spatula until mostly combined. Add the remaining flour and fold just until no dry streaks remain. Do not overmix.
8. Add the crushed potato chips and all of the chopped chocolate. Fold gently until evenly distributed.
9. Cover the dough and refrigerate for at least 12 hours, or overnight.
10. When ready to bake, preheat the oven to 350°F (175°C). Line baking sheets with parchment paper.
11. For medium cookies (recommended), scoop chilled dough with a 3-tablespoon (large) scoop, mounding it heaping. Place scoops at least 2 inches apart on the prepared sheets.
12. Bake for 10-11 minutes, or until the edges are golden but the center still looks slightly underdone and matte.
13. Let cookies cool on the baking sheet for 5 minutes, then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely.

**Tips:**
- For best results, bake the cookies directly from cold dough to prevent excessive spreading.
- If the dough is too firm to scoop after chilling, let it temper at room temperature for 10-15 minutes first.
- For smaller cookies (1.5-2 tbsp scoop), bake for 8-9 minutes. For very large cookies (a heaping ⅓ cup scoop), bake for 14-15 minutes.
- The crushed potato chips add a subtle salty crunch; they can be omitted, but they provide a savory contrast.

output:
**Chicken Satay with Peanut Sauce**

**Ingredients:**
*For the Marinade & Chicken:*
* 1 lb boneless, skinless chicken breasts or thighs
* 1 (13.5 oz) can full-fat coconut milk (divided use)
* 1 tbsp curry powder
* 1 tsp garlic powder
* 1 tbsp sugar
* 1 tsp salt
* 1/2 tsp black pepper
* Bamboo skewers (6-8 inch), soaked in water for at least 20 minutes

*For the Peanut Sauce:*
* 1 tbsp neutral oil (like vegetable or canola)
* 2 tbsp Thai red curry paste
* 1 (13.5 oz) can full-fat coconut milk (use the remainder from above)
* 1/2 cup creamy or crunchy peanut butter
* 1-2 tbsp fish sauce (or soy sauce for a plant-based version)
* 1 tbsp sugar (or to taste)

*For Garnish (Optional):*
* Sliced scallions
* Cucumber salad

**Instructions:**
1. **Soak Skewers:** Submerge bamboo skewers in water for at least 20 minutes (or overnight) to prevent burning.
2. **Make Marinade:** In a bowl, combine the dry spices: curry powder, garlic powder, sugar, salt, and pepper. Stir in approximately 3/4 cup of the coconut cream from the top of one can of coconut milk (do not shake the can) until a smooth paste forms.
3. **Prepare Chicken:** Slice the chicken against the grain into thin, flat pieces about 1 1/2 inches wide.
4. **Marinate Chicken:** Add the chicken pieces to the marinade, ensuring they are fully coated. Cover and refrigerate for at least 4 hours, or up to overnight.
5. **Make Peanut Sauce:** Heat oil in a saucepan over medium heat. Add the curry paste and fry for 1-2 minutes until fragrant. Scoop the coconut cream from the top of the second can of coconut milk into the pan and let it caramelize with the paste for another minute. Pour in the remaining coconut milk and bring to a gentle simmer.
6. **Finish Sauce:** Stir in the peanut butter until fully melted and the sauce is homogenized. Season with fish sauce and sugar to taste. Simmer until the sauce thickens enough to coat the back of a spoon. Remove from heat and set aside.
7. **Skewer Chicken:** Thread the marinated chicken pieces onto the soaked skewers, leaving the bottom third bare. Ensure no bamboo is poking through the top of the meat.
8. **Prepare Grill:** Heat a grill pan or outdoor grill to medium heat (you should be able to hold your hand 5-6 inches above the grate for about 5-6 seconds). Lightly oil the grates. For skewers, lay a folded strip of aluminum foil along the edge of the grill to protect the exposed bamboo ends from burning.
9. **Cook Satay:** Place the skewers on the foil-protected grill. Cook without moving for about 2 minutes to establish grill marks. Gently wiggle to release, then flip and cook for another 2 minutes on the other side, or until cooked through.
10. **Rest and Serve:** Let the satay rest for a few minutes. Serve warm with the peanut sauce for dipping. Garnish with sliced scallions and a side of cucumber salad if desired.

**Tips:**
- Do not shake the can of coconut milk before opening. Use the thick cream from the top to fry the curry paste and enrich the marinade.
- For plant-based satay, use extra-firm tofu and substitute soy sauce or amino acids for the fish sauce in the peanut sauce.
- This marinade and peanut sauce are versatile. They work well with pork, beef, or lamb.
- To prep ahead, you can skewer the marinated chicken and freeze it raw for later use.

**Spaghetti alla Carbonara**

**Ingredients:**
* 200g spaghetti or spaghettini
* 2 liters water
* 20g salt (for pasta water)
* 150g guanciale (or pancetta), cut into large chunks
* 1 tablespoon olive oil
* 2 large egg yolks
* 30g grated Parmesan cheese, plus extra for serving
* Freshly ground black pepper

**Instructions:**
1. Bring 2 liters of water to a rolling boil in a large pot. Add 20g of salt. Add the pasta and cook according to package instructions, stirring occasionally, until al dente (approximately 10 minutes).
2. While the pasta cooks, heat the olive oil in a large pan over medium heat. Add the chunks of guanciale and cook until crisp and golden, then remove the pan from the heat.
3. In a medium bowl, whisk the two egg yolks. Stir in the 30g of grated Parmesan and a generous amount of freshly ground black pepper to form a paste.
4. When the pasta is done, drain it and immediately add it to the pan with the guanciale. Toss well to coat the pasta in the fat and let it cool slightly for about a minute.
5. Pour the egg and cheese mixture over the warm (but not hot) pasta. Stir vigorously and continuously until the sauce becomes creamy and coats the pasta strands.
6. Serve immediately, topped with additional grated Parmesan and a final grind of black pepper.

**Tips:**
- Do not add oil to the pasta cooking water.
- The guanciale/pancetta and cheese are salty, so no additional salt is needed in the sauce.
- To prevent scrambling the eggs, ensure the pasta has cooled slightly after draining before adding the egg mixture. The residual heat should be just enough to cook the eggs into a creamy sauce.
- If desired, you can blot excess fat from the cooked guanciale with a paper towel.
