input: Sumo wrestlers eat enormous amounts of food, but the core of their diet isn't junk. It's one simple pot they rely on every single day. [music] It's called chonab. I'm Dan Martin, chef, nutritionist, and half Japanese. And today, I'll show you the version I make at home, share a bit of the culture behind it, and explain why this one pot meal works so well, not just in a sum, but in a normal healthy way of eating, too. Let's make it. Start by getting the broth going. Add water to a large pot with a strip of comoo and bring it up to a gentle boil. If you don't have comoo, a light chicken or vegetable stock works just fine. Once it's infused, remove the comoo and move on to the protein. One thing that's really synonymous with cho nab is meatballs. Traditionally, chanko is a chicken-based dish and there's a bit of symbolism behind that. Chicken stay upright on two feet, which in sumo is considered good fortune. If you end up on all fours in the ring, the match is over. Today, I'm taking in a pescatarian direction. I don't eat a huge amount of chicken and chanko is incredibly flexible. Anyway, every sumo stable in Japan has its own version. Besides, the only wrestling match I'm in these days is with my three-year-old son, and I think I've got another year or two before he starts winning. So, I'm using prawns as the base. They stay tender in the broth and soak up flavor beautifully. Let the broth settle into a gentle simmer. Use two spoons to shape small meatballs and drop them straight into the pot. When they float, they're cooked. Lift them out. Set them aside. We'll add them back in later. Now, season the broth. Add a little mirin, soy sauce, and some minced garlic. Then let the broth come back to a gentle simmer. In go the sturdier vegetables, things like carrots and the root end of the cabbage. I'll also add the shiakea mushrooms here so they can release their dashy into the broth. Once those have softened a bit, the prawn meatballs go back in along with the softer vegetables. I'm adding cod and some shellfish here because they're in season and they're in my fridge. That flexibility is part of Chanka. There's no strict recipe. Chanko started in Sumo Stables as a practical solution. One pot that could be cooked once, eaten together, and scaled up easily. It was designed to give a wrestler everything they needed nutritionally without overthinking it. And this is really why this dish works so well. At its core, it's built around complete nutrition. You've got plenty of protein to support recovery and training, loads of vegetables bring in fiber and volume, a broth that keeps everything hydrated and easy to digest, and just enough fat for flavor and satisfaction while also helping absorb fats soluble vitamins. On its own, this pot is surprisingly light for how much food you're eating, but still deeply nourishing. In sumo culture, the calories really add up because this is eaten with multiple large bowls of rice and sometimes beer on the side. That's how it becomes a very high energy meal. But the structure of the meal itself is really balanced, grounding, and easy to repeat day after day. And that's exactly what we do in my household. If you want to cook this for yourself, I've put together a printable guide in the description with this pescatarian version, a traditional chicken version, and a fully vegetarian one, too. Now, back to the pot. Turn the heat off and add the silk and tofu and finish with miso. Adding it off heat keeps the flavor bright. Then I add a small knob of butter and a sprinkle of sesame seeds. In the traditional chicken version, fat naturally renders into the broth. This does the same job here, rounding everything out and carrying all the flavor. Now ladle up. I'm having mine with a small bowl of rice and barley on the side. Leftovers are great with udon. That's dinner sorted. And if you want to build the rest of your day the same balanced way, I've got a Japanese breakfast video right here. I'll see you there.
output:
**Chanko Nabe (Sumo Stew)**

**Ingredients:**
* 8 cups water
* 1 (6-inch) strip kombu
* 1/4 cup mirin
* 1/4 cup soy sauce
* 2 cloves garlic, minced
* 1/2 lb prawns, peeled and deveined (for meatballs)
* 1 large carrot, sliced
* 1/4 head green cabbage, root end chopped, leaves separated
* 4 shiitake mushrooms, stems removed
* 4 oz firm white fish (such as cod), cut into chunks
* 4 oz shellfish (such as clams or mussels)
* 4 oz silken tofu, cubed
* 2 tbsp white miso paste
* 1 tbsp butter
* 1 tsp sesame seeds

**Instructions:**
1. In a large pot, combine the water and kombu. Bring to a gentle boil, then remove and discard the kombu. Reduce heat to a gentle simmer.
2. While the broth simmers, shape the prawns into small meatballs using two spoons. Gently drop them into the simmering broth. Once they float to the surface (about 3-4 minutes), remove them with a slotted spoon and set aside.
3. Season the broth with the mirin, soy sauce, and minced garlic. Return to a gentle simmer.
4. Add the carrot, the chopped root end of the cabbage, and the shiitake mushrooms to the pot. Simmer for 5-7 minutes until they begin to soften.
5. Return the prawn meatballs to the pot. Add the remaining cabbage leaves, white fish, and shellfish. Simmer for an additional 3-4 minutes until the fish is cooked and the shellfish have opened.
6. Turn off the heat. Gently stir in the silken tofu. Place the miso paste in a small bowl, ladle in a bit of hot broth, whisk to dissolve, then stir the mixture back into the pot.
7. Finish the stew by stirring in the butter and sprinkling with sesame seeds. Serve immediately, often with a side of rice or barley.

**Tips:**
- The broth is flexible. If you don't have kombu, you can substitute 8 cups of light chicken or vegetable stock.
- This is a template recipe. The protein (chicken, seafood, tofu) and vegetables can be swapped based on preference and seasonality.
- Always add miso off the heat to preserve its flavor and beneficial bacteria.
- Leftovers are excellent reheated and served over udon noodles.

input: today I'll show you how to make gong Japanese beef bowl I'm Nami from justan cookbook gong is a classic japanese rice for Dish and it's considered fast food in Japan let's learn to make a gudong and cook it tonight before we start don't forget to subscribe and make sure to click the Bell icon for new updates now let's get started let's make Dashi Japanese soup stock using a Dashi packet in a medium sauce pan add two two cups of water and one dashy packet start cooking over medium heat when it reaches a boil reduce the heat to medium low and shake the packet a few times to release more flavor simmer for 2 to 3 minutes and discard the pocket you'll need half2 cup of Dashi for this recipe and you can use the remaining for making miso soup now cut the onion in half and thinly slice it cut one green onion diagonally Into Thin slices and set aside cut half lound of sliced beef into pieces about 3 in wide without turning on the stove in a large frying pan add half2 cup Dashi 2 tbsp Sake 2 tblspoon mil 3 tbsp soy sauce and 1 tbspoon sugar add the onion slices and spread them throughout the pan separating the onion layers then spread the sliced beef on top of the onions cover the pan with the lid now turn on the heat to medium and start cooking once boiling skim off the scum and fat from the broth with the fine mesh schimmer this improves The Taste t the heat to a simmer and continue cooking covered for 3 to 4 minutes meanwhile serve steamed rice into large Delly bowls once it's done cooking sprinkle the green onions on top to serve put the beef and onion mixture on top of the [Music] rice garnish the gon with a pickle Red Ginger enjoy I hope you enjoy this recipe and check out more of my videos here thank you for watching and see you in the next video mat [Music]
output:
**Gyudon (Japanese Beef Bowl)**

**Ingredients:**
* 1/2 cup dashi (Japanese soup stock)
* 1/2 onion, thinly sliced
* 1/2 lb thinly sliced beef (cut into 3-inch wide pieces)
* 2 tbsp sake
* 2 tbsp mirin
* 3 tbsp soy sauce
* 1 tbsp sugar
* 1 green onion, thinly sliced on the diagonal
* Steamed rice, for serving
* Beni shoga (pickled red ginger), for garnish

**Instructions:**
1. Prepare the dashi by simmering a dashi packet in 2 cups of water for 2-3 minutes. Measure out 1/2 cup for the recipe.
2. In a large frying pan (without turning on the heat), combine the 1/2 cup dashi, sake, mirin, soy sauce, and sugar.
3. Add the sliced onion to the pan, separating the layers and spreading them out. Place the sliced beef on top of the onions in a single layer.
4. Cover the pan with a lid. Turn the heat to medium and bring to a boil.
5. Once boiling, skim off any scum and fat from the surface with a fine mesh skimmer.
6. Reduce the heat to a simmer, cover, and continue cooking for 3-4 minutes.
7. While cooking, divide steamed rice between two large bowls.
8. Once the beef is cooked, sprinkle the sliced green onion over the pan.
9. To serve, spoon the beef, onions, and sauce over the steamed rice. Garnish with pickled red ginger.

**Tips:**
- Skimming the scum and fat from the broth after it boils improves the final flavor of the dish.

**Korean Ground Beef (Gogi)**

**Ingredients:**
* 1 lb lean ground beef
* 1 small onion, sliced
* 1/4 cup soy sauce (low-sodium recommended)
* 1/4 cup packed brown sugar
* 1 tsp sesame oil
* 3-4 cloves garlic, finely chopped
* 1 thumb-sized piece of ginger, chopped
* 1/4 tsp hot pepper flakes
* 1 tsp black pepper
* 1 tbsp cooking oil
* Cooked rice, for serving
* Sliced green onions, hot chilies, and sesame seeds for garnish (optional)

**Instructions:**
1. In a bowl, combine the soy sauce, brown sugar, sesame oil, chopped garlic, chopped ginger, hot pepper flakes, and black pepper. Mix until well combined and set aside.
2. Heat the cooking oil in a pan or skillet over medium-high heat.
3. Add the ground beef to the pan and break it apart with a spoon. Cook until it is almost fully browned.
4. Add the sliced onion to the pan with the beef. Stir and fry until the beef is fully browned and the onion is translucent.
5. Pour the prepared sauce into the pan. Stir well to combine everything and bring the mixture to a boil.
6. Once boiling, reduce the heat and let it simmer for a few minutes until the sauce thickens slightly and coats the beef.
7. Serve the beef immediately over a bed of hot rice. Spoon extra sauce from the pan over the top.
8. Garnish with chopped green onions, sliced hot chilies, and sesame seeds if desired.

**Tips:**
- Adjust the amount of hot pepper flakes and fresh chilies to control the spice level.
- Using brown sugar instead of white provides a richer, molasses-like flavor to the sauce.

output:
**Shakshuka**

**Ingredients:**
* 1 large onion (or 1 ½ small onions), diced
* 1 bell pepper, diced (seeds and ribs removed)
* 4 cloves garlic, minced
* 3 tablespoons olive oil
* 1 (28 oz) can whole peeled tomatoes
* 1 teaspoon paprika
* 1 teaspoon chili powder
* 2 teaspoons ground cumin
* ½ teaspoon kosher salt (or ¼ teaspoon fine table salt), plus more to taste
* ½ teaspoon freshly cracked black pepper, plus more to taste
* 4-6 large eggs
* Fresh cilantro or parsley, chopped, for garnish
* Crumbled feta cheese, for garnish (optional)
* Crusty bread or pita, for serving

**Instructions:**
1. Heat the olive oil in a large skillet (stainless steel or well-seasoned cast iron) over medium heat until shimmering.
2. Add the diced onion and bell pepper. Cook, stirring occasionally, for 10-12 minutes until the vegetables are soft and the onions are translucent.
3. Add the paprika, chili powder, and cumin. Stir for 30 seconds until fragrant.
4. Add the minced garlic and cook, stirring constantly, for about 2 minutes to prevent burning.
5. Pour in the canned tomatoes, breaking them up with a wooden spoon. Add reserved tomato juice gradually until the desired consistency is reached (the mixture should not be watery).
6. Season with salt and pepper. Bring the sauce to a boil, then reduce the heat to a simmer. Cook uncovered for 15-20 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the sauce thickens noticeably. Taste and adjust seasoning.
7. Stir in most of the chopped cilantro or parsley, reserving some for garnish.
8. Using the back of a spoon, create small wells in the sauce. Crack an egg into a small bowl first, then carefully slide it into a well. Repeat with the remaining eggs.
9. Cover the skillet and cook until the egg whites are set and the yolks are still runny. This will take 4-12 minutes depending on your heat source (propane/gas cooks faster than electric).
10. Remove from heat. Garnish with the reserved herbs and crumbled feta cheese (if using). Serve immediately with crusty bread or pita.

**Tips:**
- For a spicier dish, substitute the bell pepper with a jalapeño or other spicy pepper.
- You can customize the vegetables (e.g., zucchini, spinach) and spices (e.g., Ras El Hanout). Add extra vegetables with the bell pepper in step 2.
- If using cast iron, avoid letting the acidic tomato sauce sit in the pan for an extended period after cooking to protect the seasoning.
